</ol>\n </div> \n</div>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sun, 25 Oct 2020 16:00:00 +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f2/Cook-Medium-Rare-Steak-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid6294870-v4-728px-Cook-Medium-Rare-Steak-Step-1-Version-3.jpg","linkMd5":"b4b44b2467870d46267d8c7956635998","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn15@2020_1/2020/10/27/16-53-43-582_d11508b3b85bf252.webp","destWidth":728,"destHeight":546,"sourceBytes":34731,"destBytes":16508,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f2/Cook-Medium-Rare-Steak-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid6294870-v4-728px-Cook-Medium-Rare-Steak-Step-1-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn15@2020_1/2020/10/27/16-53-43-582_d11508b3b85bf252.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f2/Cook-Medium-Rare-Steak-Step-2-Version-3.jpg/aid6294870-v4-728px-Cook-Medium-Rare-Steak-Step-2-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn71@2020_4/2020/10/27/16-54-19-181_8b76404af6c5eeb0.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b6/Cook-Medium-Rare-Steak-Step-3-Version-3.jpg/aid6294870-v4-728px-Cook-Medium-Rare-Steak-Step-3-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn12@2020_2/2020/10/27/16-54-21-537_43afeee9ceae82c9.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/19/Cook-Medium-Rare-Steak-Step-4-Version-3.jpg/aid6294870-v4-728px-Cook-Medium-Rare-Steak-Step-4-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn94@2020_5/2020/10/27/16-54-17-773_d5439892e21b2f21.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e6/Cook-Medium-Rare-Steak-Step-5-Version-3.jpg/aid6294870-v4-728px-Cook-Medium-Rare-Steak-Step-5-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn30@2020_3/2020/10/27/16-54-19-714_a4566ffd0b1642a0.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b1/Cook-Medium-Rare-Steak-Step-6-Version-3.jpg/aid6294870-v4-728px-Cook-Medium-Rare-Steak-Step-6-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn100@2020_4/2020/10/27/16-54-22-278_1ec498c430a5af77.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/17/Cook-Medium-Rare-Steak-Step-7-Version-3.jpg/aid6294870-v4-728px-Cook-Medium-Rare-Steak-Step-7-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn56@2020_3/2020/10/27/16-54-19-061_9e8a21a679ad85a4.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b7/Cook-Medium-Rare-Steak-Step-8-Version-3.jpg/aid6294870-v4-728px-Cook-Medium-Rare-Steak-Step-8-Version-3.jpg":null,"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8e/Cook-Medium-Rare-Steak-Step-9-Version-3.jpg/aid6294870-v4-728px-Cook-Medium-Rare-Steak-Step-9-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn46@2020_6/2020/10/27/16-54-18-484_e2cf3087ca0a1294.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/6e/Cook-Medium-Rare-Steak-Step-10-Version-3.jpg/aid6294870-v4-728px-Cook-Medium-Rare-Steak-Step-10-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn33@2020_1/2020/10/27/16-54-22-708_60aea34cfadf3ed4.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/fe/Cook-Medium-Rare-Steak-Step-11-Version-3.jpg/aid6294870-v4-728px-Cook-Medium-Rare-Steak-Step-11-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn6@2020_1/2020/10/27/16-54-15-844_38a501435e2ab20e.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9d/Cook-Medium-Rare-Steak-Step-12-Version-3.jpg/aid6294870-v4-728px-Cook-Medium-Rare-Steak-Step-12-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn91@2020_3/2020/10/27/16-54-22-308_1e5b323c7f2d5d6b.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0c/Cook-Medium-Rare-Steak-Step-13-Version-3.jpg/aid6294870-v4-728px-Cook-Medium-Rare-Steak-Step-13-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn95@2020_6/2020/10/27/16-54-15-997_4c90dd69ca1e459e.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/67/Cook-Medium-Rare-Steak-Step-14-Version-3.jpg/aid6294870-v4-728px-Cook-Medium-Rare-Steak-Step-14-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn61@2020_6/2020/10/27/16-54-17-376_e66ac32529926206.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1603817618057},{"createdTime":"2020-10-28 00:53:38","updatedTime":"2020-10-28 00:53:38","title":"How to Stay Connected Using Zoom","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\">\n <p>Staying home to fight the coronavirus pandemic likely makes you miss your friends and family. Additionally, you may be working from home to help limit the spread of the virus. Fortunately, you can use Zoom to connect with your friends and coworkers. With a free account, you can have an unlimited amount of 40-minute long face-to-face video meetings with up to 100 participants. When your 40-minute meeting ends, create another one if you want to keep the party going! </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Creating a Zoom Account\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Creating-a-Zoom-Account\">Creating a Zoom Account</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Enter your email to sign up for a free account. Go to Zoom’s website and enter your email account in the space provided. Click on the button that says “Sign up, It’s Free” to get an email sent to your account.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom-Step-1.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Stay Connected Using Zoom Step 1.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/61/Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom-Step-1.jpg/aid11810944-v4-728px-Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom-Step-1.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Sign up here: <a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://zoom.us/freesignup/\">https://zoom.us/freesignup/</a></li> \n    <li>You can also sign up using your Google account or Facebook account.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Open the Zoom email to create your account. Go to your email and click on the email sent by Zoom. Follow the instructions in the email to verify your account. Provide your name and a password to complete your free profile.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom-Step-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Stay Connected Using Zoom Step 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c6/Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom-Step-2.jpg/aid11810944-v4-728px-Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom-Step-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you want more features, you can upgrade your account for $14.99 a month. However, a free account is all you need to stay connected with the people you care about.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Download the Zoom meetings software to your computer and devices. After you have an account, visit the Zoom download’s page to access the free software. Look at the top of the webpage for Zoom Client for Meetings. Then, click the “download” button to install it on your computer, tablet, and/or mobile phone.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom-Step-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Stay Connected Using Zoom Step 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d0/Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom-Step-3.jpg/aid11810944-v4-728px-Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom-Step-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You can download Zoom here: <a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://zoom.us/download?zcid=1231\">https://zoom.us/download?zcid=1231</a></li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Sign in to your Zoom account. Go back to the Zoom website and click on the “Sign In” link in the top right corner. Enter your email and password to sign into your free account. You can now use Zoom meetings to connect with your friends, family, or coworkers.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom-Step-4.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Stay Connected Using Zoom Step 4.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/6c/Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom-Step-4.jpg/aid11810944-v4-728px-Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom-Step-4.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Check that your webcam and mic are working. You’ll need a webcam and mic on your device to participate in a Zoom meeting. Test yours out to make sure they work.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom-Step-5.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Stay Connected Using Zoom Step 5.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9b/Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom-Step-5.jpg/aid11810944-v4-728px-Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom-Step-5.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you don’t have a working webcam and mic, you can purchase an external cam and/or headset to make Zoom functional for you.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Spending Time with Friends and Family\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Spending-Time-with-Friends-and-Family\">Spending Time with Friends and Family</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Host a Zoom dinner party. Schedule a time for your dinner party, then set up a meeting in Zoom. Send all of your invitees a link to your meeting and tell them when to log on. Ask each person to prepare their meal in time to join the group dinner party.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom-Step-6.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Stay Connected Using Zoom Step 6.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a7/Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom-Step-6.jpg/aid11810944-v4-728px-Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom-Step-6.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>For households with multiple members, ask them to place their computer, tablet, phone or webcam at the end of the table so each family member is visible in the feed.</li> \n    <li>If you’re doing a family party, you might encourage everyone to make a cherished family recipe.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Enjoy a drink together like old times using a Zoom meeting. If you’d normally meet up with your friends for happy hour or drinks on the weekend, move your social hour online instead. Choose a time that works for all of your friends, then create a meeting in Zoom and send everyone the link. Gather around your computers, tablets, or phones at the designated time and sip on your favorite beer, wine, or cocktails.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom-Step-7.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Stay Connected Using Zoom Step 7.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9c/Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom-Step-7.jpg/aid11810944-v4-728px-Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom-Step-7.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Use this time to blow off steam and chat about your lives.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Schedule a movie night over Zoom. Like many people, you’re probably watching a lot of TV shows and movies right now. Make your TV time more fun by sharing it with friends or family. Pick a movie or TV show to watch together, then host a watch party over Zoom. Encourage each person to snack on their favorite popcorn or candy for added fun.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom-Step-8.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Stay Connected Using Zoom Step 8.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/24/Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom-Step-8.jpg/aid11810944-v4-728px-Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom-Step-8.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Share your reactions to the movie or TV show with your friends or family.</li> \n    <li>Show each other your snacks or treats.</li> \n    <li>Discuss the movie or TV show afterwards.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Use Zoom to discuss or participate in a shared interest or hobby. You and your friends or family members likely have some shared interests you can explore on Zoom. Talk to your friends and family about what interests or hobbies they’d like to discuss or do together. Tell everyone what the topic will be before the meeting so they can be prepared. Here are some ideas:<sup id=\"_ref-10\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom#_note-10\">[10]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom-Step-9.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Stay Connected Using Zoom Step 9.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/cb/Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom-Step-9.jpg/aid11810944-v4-728px-Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom-Step-9.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Host a book club meeting.</li> \n    <li>Discuss ideas and recipes for brewing your own beer.</li> \n    <li>Knit.</li> \n    <li>Play improv games.</li> \n    <li>Do a reading of a play.</li> \n    <li>Build Lego projects.</li> \n    <li>Draw or paint together.</li> \n    <li>Share and critique stories or poems.</li> \n    <li>Discuss your pets or children.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Play a role-playing game, online game, or board game together. You might think game nights are out of the question right now, but it’s totally possible to host one online. Pick a game with your friends or family members, and schedule a time for game night. Here are some ideas for games you could play:<sup id=\"_ref-11\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom#_note-11\">[11]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom-Step-10.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Stay Connected Using Zoom Step 10.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8e/Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom-Step-10.jpg/aid11810944-v4-728px-Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom-Step-10.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Role-playing games are easy because only the game master needs to have the materials.</li> \n    <li>Online games also work well if everyone has a gaming account.</li> \n    <li>Tabletop games can work if everyone has the same game. You could also play a game that uses dice if everyone has a set of dice. Have one person move all of the pieces on the board, but let each player roll their own dice.</li> \n    <li>If someone has access to Jackbox games, everyone can play using the shared-screen function.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Host a karaoke night using a Zoom meeting. Singing karaoke together can take your online party to the next level. Ask each invitee to look up their favorite karaoke songs on YouTube. Then, have the person singing share their screen so everyone can see the song lyrics during the performance.<sup id=\"_ref-12\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 12\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom#_note-12\">[12]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom-Step-11.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Stay Connected Using Zoom Step 11.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d9/Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom-Step-11.jpg/aid11810944-v4-728px-Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom-Step-11.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You can choose to skip the screen sharing part if you prefer.</li> \n    <li>Treat this like any other karaoke night by enjoying the drinks and snacks you’d usually consume with your friends or family.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Working and Connecting with Coworkers\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Working-and-Connecting-with-Coworkers\">Working and Connecting with Coworkers</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Use a virtual background to hide your home if you like. You don’t need to worry about whether or not your house is clean or your kids are running around. If you’re concerned about people seeing inside your home, activate a Zoom virtual background. Other users will see the virtual background behind you instead of what’s really there.<sup id=\"_ref-13\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 13\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom#_note-13\">[13]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom-Step-12.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Stay Connected Using Zoom Step 12.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/33/Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom-Step-12.jpg/aid11810944-v4-728px-Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom-Step-12.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Zoom has a lot of options ranging from plain backgrounds to destinations.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Mute and unmute yourself as needed to help protect your privacy. During your work meetings, it’s easy to mute and unmute your mic using either your mouse or your space bar. Simply click on the “mute” button or press the space bar.<sup id=\"_ref-14\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 14\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom#_note-14\">[14]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom-Step-13.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Stay Connected Using Zoom Step 13.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/61/Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom-Step-13.jpg/aid11810944-v4-728px-Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom-Step-13.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>The mute function is great for blocking out noise from your children or pets. Plus, your work group can limit background noise if people mute when they aren’t talking.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Host work meetings on Zoom so employees can collaborate. Schedule your work meetings with coworkers, then send everyone a link to the Zoom meeting. While in a Zoom meeting, users can do screen sharing to boost collaboration. It’s even possible for multiple team members to share their screens with each other so all team members can see the same information.<sup id=\"_ref-15\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 15\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom#_note-15\">[15]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom-Step-14.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Stay Connected Using Zoom Step 14.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/cc/Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom-Step-14.jpg/aid11810944-v4-728px-Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom-Step-14.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>There’s also a chat function in the meeting if members prefer to send each other typed messages while they’re collaborating.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Do a webinar if you’re conducting a slide presentation. Zoom's webinar function works best for slide presentations because this format puts the focus on your presentation and shares it to each viewer’s screen. You’ll still be able to see your attendee’s faces along the side bar during the presentation. Additionally, attendees can still make comments.<sup id=\"_ref-16\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 16\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom#_note-16\">[16]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom-Step-15.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Stay Connected Using Zoom Step 15.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8a/Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom-Step-15.jpg/aid11810944-v4-728px-Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom-Step-15.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You can also record your webinar so people can watch the presentation later if they miss it.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Socialize on Zoom to help maintain work relationships. You probably miss hanging out with your coworkers, and Zoom can help with that, as well. In addition to work meetings and webinars, schedule social meetups on Zoom so you and your coworkers can stay connected. Here are some ideas:<sup id=\"_ref-17\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 17\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom#_note-17\">[17]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom-Step-16.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Stay Connected Using Zoom Step 16.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/ba/Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom-Step-16.jpg/aid11810944-v4-728px-Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom-Step-16.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Schedule a weekly “lunch” with your coworkers using a Zoom meeting.</li> \n    <li>Enjoy a “happy hour” on Zoom.</li> \n    <li>Host a casual networking event or “get to know” you party.</li> \n    <li>Do a training or continuing education program together.</li> \n    <li>Introduce your pets to each other.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Tips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tips\">Tips</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Try out different types of events so you and the people important to you feel like you have active social lives.</li> \n  <li>Make sure the times you pick work for everyone in your group. Some of your friends may still be working, so choose a time that works for them.</li> \n  <li>Don’t give up on Zoom if the first few meetings are a bit rocky. It may take time for everyone to learn how to best use this tool for staying connected.</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: References\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"References\">References</span></h2>\n <div class=\"mw-references-wrap mw-references-columns\">\n  <ol rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://zoom.us/freesignup/\">https://zoom.us/freesignup/</a></span> </li> \n   <li id=\"_note-2\"><a target=\"_blank\" </div> \n</div>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 23 Oct 2020 08:00:00 +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/61/Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom-Step-1.jpg/aid11810944-v4-728px-Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom-Step-1.jpg","linkMd5":"7a15c81dabd8e97bc6e8e8ec38692c8e","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn28@2020_5/2020/10/27/16-53-44-038_f413d55aab904e71.webp","destWidth":728,"destHeight":546,"sourceBytes":58241,"destBytes":33382,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/61/Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom-Step-1.jpg/aid11810944-v4-728px-Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom-Step-1.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn28@2020_5/2020/10/27/16-53-44-038_f413d55aab904e71.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c6/Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom-Step-2.jpg/aid11810944-v4-728px-Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom-Step-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn89@2020_6/2020/10/27/16-54-21-574_03afc798c3962d76.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d0/Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom-Step-3.jpg/aid11810944-v4-728px-Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom-Step-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn80@2020_2/2020/10/27/16-54-22-126_79667e9e15c1c8e3.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/6c/Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom-Step-4.jpg/aid11810944-v4-728px-Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom-Step-4.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn38@2020_1/2020/10/27/16-54-18-159_129cb1d04282abd0.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9b/Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom-Step-5.jpg/aid11810944-v4-728px-Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom-Step-5.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn37@2020_4/2020/10/27/16-54-16-286_7b2b233147605f7f.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a7/Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom-Step-6.jpg/aid11810944-v4-728px-Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom-Step-6.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn54@2020_5/2020/10/27/16-54-17-381_293ab1c1c8889f36.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9c/Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom-Step-7.jpg/aid11810944-v4-728px-Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom-Step-7.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn66@2020_1/2020/10/27/16-54-17-443_8af65b054a63038e.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/24/Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom-Step-8.jpg/aid11810944-v4-728px-Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom-Step-8.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn55@2020_5/2020/10/27/16-54-22-915_dc3e3e9ab7163362.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/cb/Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom-Step-9.jpg/aid11810944-v4-728px-Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom-Step-9.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn92@2020_6/2020/10/27/16-54-18-652_9b05c7425128f3af.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8e/Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom-Step-10.jpg/aid11810944-v4-728px-Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom-Step-10.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn86@2020_4/2020/10/27/16-54-22-863_ef88c94949781c1d.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d9/Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom-Step-11.jpg/aid11810944-v4-728px-Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom-Step-11.jpg":null,"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/33/Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom-Step-12.jpg/aid11810944-v4-728px-Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom-Step-12.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn70@2020_3/2020/10/27/16-54-22-179_bcc1a7a7a7041950.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/61/Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom-Step-13.jpg/aid11810944-v4-728px-Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom-Step-13.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn46@2020_3/2020/10/27/16-54-19-763_0db597f34d197efc.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/cc/Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom-Step-14.jpg/aid11810944-v4-728px-Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom-Step-14.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn68@2020_1/2020/10/27/16-54-19-290_bae169da5da642d3.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8a/Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom-Step-15.jpg/aid11810944-v4-728px-Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom-Step-15.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn15@2020_1/2020/10/27/16-54-18-762_c251f6ee72f37354.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/ba/Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom-Step-16.jpg/aid11810944-v4-728px-Stay-Connected-Using-Zoom-Step-16.jpg":null},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1603817618056},{"createdTime":"2020-10-28 00:53:38","updatedTime":"2020-10-28 00:53:38","title":"How to Distinguish Between CPTSD and Autism","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Distinguish-Between-CPTSD-and-Autism","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\">\n <p>Finding an accurate diagnosis can be difficult for someone with one or more undiagnosed mental conditions. If you suspect autism or CPTSD (Complex Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder), it can be hard to distinguish between the two, whether you're looking at signs in yourself or a loved one. This article can help you figure out whether you're dealing with one of these, both of these, or something else. </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Distinguish-Between-CPTSD-and-Autism&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Distinguish-Between-CPTSD-and-Autism&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Looking at Signs\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Looking-at-Signs\">Looking at Signs</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Notice the shared signs of autism and CPTSD. Both autistic people and those with CPTSD have social troubles, and may be fearful, with difficulties coping. They can be easily confused with each other. Both autism and CPTSD can involve...<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Distinguish-Between-CPTSD-and-Autism#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup><sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Distinguish-Between-CPTSD-and-Autism#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup> \n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Person-in-Yellow-at-the-Beach.png\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Person in Yellow at the Beach.png\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/26/Person-in-Yellow-at-the-Beach.png/728px-Person-in-Yellow-at-the-Beach.png\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"485\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Extremely strong or inhibited emotions</li> \n    <li>Feeling different from everyone else, though perhaps not knowing why</li> \n    <li>Difficulty forming and maintaining relationships</li> \n    <li>Social difficulties</li> \n    <li>Enjoyment of being alone</li> \n    <li>Hyperactivity or passivity</li> \n    <li>Startling easily</li> \n    <li>Repetitive movements</li> \n    <li>Sleep issues</li> \n    <li>Perfectionism and need for control</li> \n    <li>Stress-related troubles</li> \n    <li>Avoidance of eye contact</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Rule out CPTSD if no trauma is present—but be cautious, since trauma isn't always easy to spot. Autism is inborn,<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Distinguish-Between-CPTSD-and-Autism#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup> while CPTSD only happens to people who suffer prolonged trauma. CPTSD can be caused by dramatically stressful events, or more subtle ones. Consider if the person has ever experienced... \n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Adult-Criticizes-Young-Teen.png\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Adult Criticizes Young Teen.png\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/77/Adult-Criticizes-Young-Teen.png/728px-Adult-Criticizes-Young-Teen.png\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"485\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Abuse or neglect (including emotional neglect)</li> \n    <li>Name-calling, ignoring, or frequent criticism from mentors or loved ones</li> \n    <li>Bullying victimization</li> \n    <li>Long-term exposure to crisis conditions</li> \n    <li>Discrimination</li> \n    <li>Stalking victimization</li> \n    <li>Gaslighting</li> \n    <li>Other types of mistreatment</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Look at the nature of repetitive movements. People with CPTSD may use repetitive movements, like rocking back and forth, to cope with severe stress. Autistic people may move repetitively under stress, but may also do it to focus, express feelings, or have fun. Ask yourself if the person ever moves repetitively when they're happy or calm.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Distinguish-Between-CPTSD-and-Autism#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup> \n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Autistic-Teen-Flaps-Hands-in-Delight.png\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Autistic Teen Flaps Hands in Delight.png\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8e/Autistic-Teen-Flaps-Hands-in-Delight.png/728px-Autistic-Teen-Flaps-Hands-in-Delight.png\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"485\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Look at the reason for social difficulties. Autistic people deal with social confusion, and may have trouble understanding what others are thinking and feeling. Communication is a challenge. People with CPTSD can be fearful or moody, and may self-isolate.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Distinguish-Between-CPTSD-and-Autism#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup> \n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Person-Wants-Not-To-Be-Touched.png\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Person Wants Not To Be Touched.png\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/95/Person-Wants-Not-To-Be-Touched.png/728px-Person-Wants-Not-To-Be-Touched.png\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"485\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>A healthy autistic person usually wants to have some friends. Someone with CPTSD may feel safer when they're alone.</li> \n    <li>An autistic person may struggle to understand what others are thinking. Someone with CPTSD may be overly pessimistic about what others are thinking.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Consider why the person gets overwhelmed. Autistic people often get overwhelmed due to sensory issues. People with CPTSD deal with hypervigilance (which can be exhausting), and may have panic attacks due to a trigger in the environment.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Distinguish-Between-CPTSD-and-Autism#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup> \n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Autistic-Teen-Covers-Ears.png\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Autistic Teen Covers Ears.png\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9f/Autistic-Teen-Covers-Ears.png/728px-Autistic-Teen-Covers-Ears.png\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"485\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Autistic people usually have <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Diagnose-Sensory-Processing-Disorder\" title=\"Diagnose Sensory Processing Disorder\">Sensory Processing Disorder</a>, which can make their senses over- or under-sensitive. They may avoid things for sensory reasons.</li> \n    <li>People with CPTSD can have emotional flashbacks and trauma triggers. They may avoid things that remind them of their trauma.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Consider the person's routines. Both autistic people and people with CPTSD may rely on routines to help them feel like the world is a safe and predictable place.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Distinguish-Between-CPTSD-and-Autism#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup> \n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Person-and-Golden-Retriever-Take-a-Walk.png\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Person and Golden Retriever Take a Walk.png\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e0/Person-and-Golden-Retriever-Take-a-Walk.png/728px-Person-and-Golden-Retriever-Take-a-Walk.png\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"485\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>People with CPTSD may or may not like routine. If they do, it may help them avoid triggers and hypervigilance.</li> \n    <li>Autistic people rely on routine. Routines make it easier to get things done,<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Distinguish-Between-CPTSD-and-Autism#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup> and a change in routine can be startling and distressing to them.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Look at what causes sleeping issues. Autistic people's bodies may not produce enough melatonin naturally, and taking melatonin supplements before bed can improve sleep. People with CPTSD have trouble falling asleep due to stress, and may have frequent or dramatic nightmares. \n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Sleeping-Girl-with-Flannel-Sheets.png\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Sleeping Girl with Flannel Sheets.png\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/14/Sleeping-Girl-with-Flannel-Sheets.png/728px-Sleeping-Girl-with-Flannel-Sheets.png\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"485\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Look for signs of autism that don't overlap with CPTSD. <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Understand-Autism\" title=\"Understand Autism\">Autism</a> involves developmental delays and quirks, passionate interests, difficulty understanding speech, and unusual speech. None of these are typical in CPTSD. \n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Confused-Teen.png\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Confused Teen.png\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/ff/Confused-Teen.png/728px-Confused-Teen.png\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"485\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li><b>Developmental timeline:</b> Milestones may be met late or out of order. Consider early childhood milestones as well as later ones like riding a bike, swimming, doing laundry, driving, and living independently.</li> \n    <li><b>Interests:</b> Autistic people usually have one or a few subjects that they're very passionate about. They love talking about them, and can hyperfocus on them for a long time. They may also feel lots of empathy for animals and objects.</li> \n    <li><b>Trouble understanding speech:</b> An autistic person may have a hard time understanding verbal speech, especially if the acoustics are different (e.g. in an auditorium, or sound from speakers). They may be confused by figurative language.</li> \n    <li><b>Differences in speaking:</b> Their speech may be halting, slow, and/or unusual in pitch or tone. They may lose the ability to speak when they are too stressed, or be unable to speak at all.</li> \n    <li><b>Co-occurring issues:</b> Autistic people are likely to have <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Diagnose-Sensory-Processing-Disorder\" title=\"Diagnose Sensory Processing Disorder\">Sensory Processing Disorder</a>, and often have <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Live-with-Dyspraxia\" title=\"Live with Dyspraxia\">dyspraxia</a> (which can look like clumsiness). <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Diagnose-Auditory-Processing-Disorder\" title=\"Diagnose Auditory Processing Disorder\">Auditory Processing Disorder</a> is also common.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Distinguish-Between-CPTSD-and-Autism&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Seeking Diagnosis\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Seeking-Diagnosis\">Seeking Diagnosis</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Research both autism and CPTSD. Read clinical papers, and also personal stories from people who have one or both conditions. This can give you a better sense of each condition, and help you understand it from a more personal perspective. \n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Hijabi-Girl-at-Computer.png\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Hijabi Girl at Computer.png\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/07/Hijabi-Girl-at-Computer.png/728px-Hijabi-Girl-at-Computer.png\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"485\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Consider the possibility of both conditions. Unfortunately, autistic people are at increased risk of abuse and other problems in life, and may be more likely to develop PTSD or CPTSD in response to trauma.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Distinguish-Between-CPTSD-and-Autism#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup><sup id=\"_ref-10\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Distinguish-Between-CPTSD-and-Autism#_note-10\">[10]</a></sup><sup id=\"_ref-11\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Distinguish-Between-CPTSD-and-Autism#_note-11\">[11]</a></sup> \n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Jewish-Guy-with-an-Idea.png\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Jewish Guy with an Idea.png\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/57/Jewish-Guy-with-an-Idea.png/728px-Jewish-Guy-with-an-Idea.png\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"485\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>What's stressful or scary to a non-autistic person could be traumatic to an autistic person. If the symptoms are real, then the trauma is real, even if other people don't consider the events \"traumatic enough.\"</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Consider the possibility of a different condition. If the traits described here don't quite match what you or your loved one is going through, or they describe some but not all of what's going on, it's possible that another condition is at play. It may also be useful to read about and consider... \n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Various-Stressed-People.png\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Various Stressed People.png\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/69/Various-Stressed-People.png/728px-Various-Stressed-People.png\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"485\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Define-ADHD\" title=\"Define ADHD\">ADHD</a></li> \n    <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Recognize-Social-Anxiety-Disorder\" title=\"Recognize Social Anxiety Disorder\">Social anxiety</a></li> \n    <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Identify-Schizoid-Personality-Disorder\" title=\"Identify Schizoid Personality Disorder\">Schizoid personality disorder</a></li> \n    <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Treat-Reactive-Attachment-Disorder\" title=\"Treat Reactive Attachment Disorder\">Reactive attachment</a> (in children)</li> \n    <li>Attachment disorders</li> \n    <li>Something else</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Avoid jumping to a conclusion early on. Getting too attached to a diagnosis, without fully understanding it, could make you miss what is really going on. CPTSD treatment is very different from supports for autism, so it's important to get it right. \n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Jewish-Guy-Says-No-2.png\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Jewish Guy Says No 2.png\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/71/Jewish-Guy-Says-No-2.png/728px-Jewish-Guy-Says-No-2.png\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"485\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Talk to a doctor or specialist for advice. Look for someone who works with autistic people, and people with trauma, if you can. Talk to them about the signs you're experiencing, and ask for an evaluation. \n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Therapist-in-Green.png\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Therapist in Green.png\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c9/Therapist-in-Green.png/728px-Therapist-in-Green.png\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"485\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Be-Ready-for-an-Autism-Assessment\" title=\"Be Ready for an Autism Assessment\">Come prepared</a>. Try writing down a list of symptoms. If you took any online tests, fill out your answers to each question in pencil, and bring it along.</li> \n    <li>Speak up if you're concerned about misdiagnosis. A specialist is only as good as the information they have. If you think that there's a piece of the picture that they're missing, talk about it.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Distinguish-Between-CPTSD-and-Autism&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Tips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tips\">Tips</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Stay away from overly negative sources about autism, like <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Boycott-Autism-Speaks\" title=\"Boycott Autism Speaks\">Autism Speaks</a>. Some groups say things that are inaccurate, or that are worse-case scenarios. They may scare you into believing things that aren't true. This isn't healthy or constructive.</li> \n  <li>Trauma isn't always remembered. People with CPTSD may forget traumatic events, though they may recall them later.<sup id=\"_ref-12\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 12\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Distinguish-Between-CPTSD-and-Autism#_note-12\">[12]</a></sup> Traumatic events can also occur during infant or toddler years, meaning they may not be remembered, but can still have an impact.</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Distinguish-Between-CPTSD-and-Autism&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Related wikiHows\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Related-wikiHows\">Related wikiHows</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Understand-Autism\" title=\"Understand Autism\">Understand Autism</a></li> \n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Recognize-the-Signs-of-CPTSD\" title=\"Recognize the Signs of CPTSD\">Recognize the Signs of CPTSD</a></li> \n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Recognize-Signs-of-Autism-in-Yourself\" title=\"Recognize Signs of Autism in Yourself\">Recognize Signs of Autism in Yourself</a></li> \n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Be-Ready-for-an-Autism-Assessment\" title=\"Be Ready for an Autism Assessment\">Be Ready for an Autism Assessment</a></li> \n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cope-with-an-Autism-Diagnosis\" title=\"Cope with an Autism Diagnosis\">Cope with an Autism Diagnosis</a></li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Distinguish-Between-CPTSD-and-Autism&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: References\">Edit</a><span +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/26/Person-in-Yellow-at-the-Beach.png/728px-Person-in-Yellow-at-the-Beach.png","linkMd5":"d7754ad694c2fef2acac76494b5e31e8","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn35@2020_3/2020/10/27/16-53-38-585_a81a8a39bef5fd10.webp","destWidth":728,"destHeight":485,"sourceBytes":327817,"destBytes":24244,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/26/Person-in-Yellow-at-the-Beach.png/728px-Person-in-Yellow-at-the-Beach.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn35@2020_3/2020/10/27/16-53-38-585_a81a8a39bef5fd10.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/77/Adult-Criticizes-Young-Teen.png/728px-Adult-Criticizes-Young-Teen.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn30@2020_1/2020/10/27/16-54-18-764_b1ac5619f092574c.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8e/Autistic-Teen-Flaps-Hands-in-Delight.png/728px-Autistic-Teen-Flaps-Hands-in-Delight.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn92@2020_2/2020/10/27/16-54-16-282_e94d6b417e5ee0b1.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/95/Person-Wants-Not-To-Be-Touched.png/728px-Person-Wants-Not-To-Be-Touched.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn29@2020_5/2020/10/27/16-54-18-254_04c953de31933dc3.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9f/Autistic-Teen-Covers-Ears.png/728px-Autistic-Teen-Covers-Ears.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn62@2020_1/2020/10/27/16-54-21-372_cb5644b1e33d70f8.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e0/Person-and-Golden-Retriever-Take-a-Walk.png/728px-Person-and-Golden-Retriever-Take-a-Walk.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn46@2020_5/2020/10/27/16-54-20-530_399a769c261e7654.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/14/Sleeping-Girl-with-Flannel-Sheets.png/728px-Sleeping-Girl-with-Flannel-Sheets.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn60@2020_1/2020/10/27/16-54-16-006_e1f5953b8c31fe7c.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/ff/Confused-Teen.png/728px-Confused-Teen.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn37@2020_2/2020/10/27/16-54-22-698_2a84c6e38465df67.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/07/Hijabi-Girl-at-Computer.png/728px-Hijabi-Girl-at-Computer.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn70@2020_5/2020/10/27/16-54-20-797_0d510f76459eb163.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/57/Jewish-Guy-with-an-Idea.png/728px-Jewish-Guy-with-an-Idea.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn2@2020_5/2020/10/27/16-54-15-998_085afc7b36aabf01.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/69/Various-Stressed-People.png/728px-Various-Stressed-People.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn7@2020_2/2020/10/27/16-54-20-079_edb2cd65700a37f3.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/71/Jewish-Guy-Says-No-2.png/728px-Jewish-Guy-Says-No-2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn16@2020_1/2020/10/27/16-54-19-441_6f2c182ae9a42b16.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c9/Therapist-in-Green.png/728px-Therapist-in-Green.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn96@2020_4/2020/10/27/16-54-18-748_b070e3b31d04ea66.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1603817618055},{"createdTime":"2020-10-28 00:53:38","updatedTime":"2020-10-28 00:53:38","title":"How to Cancel a Credit Card","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Cancel-a-Credit-Card","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\">\n <p>If your credit card is costing you too much money or you just have too many of them, you may decide that it's time to close the account. This is a relatively easy process that can be done almost entirely over the phone. Because canceling a credit card can affect your credit score, it's important to be strategic about it and do whatever you can to defend your credit. </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Cancel-a-Credit-Card&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Cancel-a-Credit-Card&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Contacting Your Credit Card Issuer to Cancel the Card\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Contacting-Your-Credit-Card-Issuer-to-Cancel-the-Card\">Contacting Your Credit Card Issuer to Cancel the Card</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Pay it off first. Before you cancel your credit card, it's a good idea to make sure that you pay off the existing balance and stop using the card. If you can't afford to pay it off, you can transfer the balance to another card that you do not plan on canceling.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cancel-a-Credit-Card#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Get-a-Credit-Card-With-No-Credit-Step-10-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Get a Credit Card With No Credit Step 10 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1d/Get-a-Credit-Card-With-No-Credit-Step-10-Version-2.jpg/aid460007-v4-728px-Get-a-Credit-Card-With-No-Credit-Step-10-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>When you call to cancel your card, confirm that there is no balance on it.</li> \n    <li>In addition to paying off your balance, you should also make sure that you cash out all of your rewards. If you forget to do this, they will likely be lost forever.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Call the customer service department. In order to cancel your card, you will need to contact the issuer's customer service department. The number can usually be found on the back of your card, on your bill, and online. Once you are connected to a customer service agent, let them know that you would like to close your account.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cancel-a-Credit-Card#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Contact-the-IRS-Step-17.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Contact the IRS Step 17.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d5/Contact-the-IRS-Step-17.jpg/aid460007-v4-728px-Contact-the-IRS-Step-17.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Have your credit card and a bill in front of you when you call. This will ensure that you will have all of the information you will need.</li> \n    <li>The representative may ask you why you want to close the account. You can give any reason you like, including that you do not use the card. It is your right to close the account for any reason at all.</li> \n    <li>If possible, get the representative's name or ID number and write it down, just in case you have problems later.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cancel-a-Credit-Card#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Consider the counter-offer. When you call to cancel your card, the issuer may offer you something, such as a lower interest rate or more rewards points, to keep you as a customer. It may or may not be worth it to consider this offer, depending on why you want to cancel the card in the first place.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cancel-a-Credit-Card#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Develop-a-Relationship-With-a-Customer-Step-5-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Develop a Relationship With a Customer Step 5 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/63/Develop-a-Relationship-With-a-Customer-Step-5-Version-3.jpg/aid460007-v4-728px-Develop-a-Relationship-With-a-Customer-Step-5-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>It's a good idea to think about what it would take to change your mind about canceling before you call. This will make it easier for you to stand your ground if the offer isn't good enough.</li> \n    <li>If the offer is good, you may want to consider canceling a different credit card instead.</li> \n    <li>If you're on the fence about closing the card, you can try calling the customer service department and bargaining with them for better terms. For example, you might say, \"I plan on canceling this card unless you can lower my interest rate to 15%.\"</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Confirm the cancellation in writing. If you end up canceling your card over the phone, it's always a good idea to send the company a letter as well. This will help ensure that the account is really canceled, even if the customer service agent you spoke to makes a mistake.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cancel-a-Credit-Card#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Announce-Your-Retirement-Step-8.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Announce Your Retirement Step 8.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3a/Announce-Your-Retirement-Step-8.jpg/aid460007-v4-728px-Announce-Your-Retirement-Step-8.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>The letter must include your name, address, and credit card account number.</li> \n    <li>Include the date that you canceled the card and the name of the representative you spoke to in your letter, and request that the company send you a written confirmation letter indicating that the card has been canceled.</li> \n    <li>You may want to include proof of your final payment, such as a copy of a check.</li> \n    <li>Send the letter by certified mail with a return receipt.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Cancel-a-Credit-Card&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Protecting Your Credit Score When You Cancel a Credit Card\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Protecting-Your-Credit-Score-When-You-Cancel-a-Credit-Card\">Protecting Your Credit Score When You Cancel a Credit Card</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Pick the right time to cancel. Since canceling a credit card can influence your credit score, it's important to be strategic about when you do it. Avoid closing any accounts if you are in the process applying for new credit.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cancel-a-Credit-Card#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Prepare-a-Power-of-Attorney-Step-2-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Prepare a Power of Attorney Step 2 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3f/Prepare-a-Power-of-Attorney-Step-2-Version-3.jpg/aid460007-v4-728px-Prepare-a-Power-of-Attorney-Step-2-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you are planning to buy a house or a new car, wait until after the loan is finalized to cancel your card.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Consider off-setting the cancellation. In order to avoid hurting your <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Understand-Your-FICO-Credit-Score\" title=\"Understand Your FICO Credit Score\">credit score</a> by canceling a card, you may want to off-set it by increasing your credit limit in another way. This will keep your credit utilization rate constant.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cancel-a-Credit-Card#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Get-a-Credit-Card-With-No-Credit-Step-1-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Get a Credit Card With No Credit Step 1 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a0/Get-a-Credit-Card-With-No-Credit-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid460007-v4-728px-Get-a-Credit-Card-With-No-Credit-Step-1-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You can do this by opening a new card or requesting a balance increase on an existing card.</li> \n    <li>If you have good credit and low balances on your cards, this is less important. Closing a credit card should only have a small impact on your credit score.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Choose the right cards to cancel. If you want to cancel a credit card simply because you have too many of them, it's important to think carefully about which one you should cancel. Canceling the wrong card could end up costing you more money or damaging your credit score unnecessarily.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cancel-a-Credit-Card#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Get-a-Credit-Card-With-No-Credit-Step-13-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Get a Credit Card With No Credit Step 13 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0b/Get-a-Credit-Card-With-No-Credit-Step-13-Version-2.jpg/aid460007-v4-728px-Get-a-Credit-Card-With-No-Credit-Step-13-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Cards that charge annual fees or have very high interest rates are usually the best options (unless these cards come with benefits that outweigh the high costs).</li> \n    <li>Canceling the credit card that you have had for the longest is usually a bad idea because continuous credit looks good on your credit report.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Look at your credit report after canceling. After you cancel your credit card, it's a good idea to <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Check-Your-Credit-Score\" title=\"Check Your Credit Score\">request a copy of your credit report</a> and look at it carefully to confirm that it reflects the fact that you have canceled the card. It should not say that the account was closed by the issuer, as this will look bad to other creditors.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cancel-a-Credit-Card#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Write-a-Grant-Proposal-Step-17-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Write a Grant Proposal Step 17 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/fd/Write-a-Grant-Proposal-Step-17-Version-3.jpg/aid460007-v4-728px-Write-a-Grant-Proposal-Step-17-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If your credit report is inaccurate, you will need to contact the credit card company's customer service department again and ask them to correct the way in which they reported the closure of the account to the credit reporting agency. Be sure to check your report again to make sure they fixed the problem.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Cancel-a-Credit-Card&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Tips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tips\">Tips</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Once you've canceled your credit card, you can dispose of it by shredding it or cutting it into small pieces and putting it in the trash.</li> \n  <li>There's no way to predict exactly how much of an effect canceling a card will have on your credit score, as it is considered along with many other factors. This is why it's best to avoid closing any accounts right before you plan on applying for a big loan.</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Cancel-a-Credit-Card&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Related wikiHows\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Related-wikiHows\">Related wikiHows</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li><a target=\"_blank\"
