+0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e1/Propagate-Air-Plants-Step-1.jpg/aid11719527-v4-728px-Propagate-Air-Plants-Step-1.jpg","linkMd5":"6bfdb47ad18fedc32271f3b3780ed6e3","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn18@2020_1/2020/10/27/16-53-38-509_366be17b9a0d0024.webp","destWidth":728,"destHeight":546,"sourceBytes":120413,"destBytes":83966,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e1/Propagate-Air-Plants-Step-1.jpg/aid11719527-v4-728px-Propagate-Air-Plants-Step-1.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn18@2020_1/2020/10/27/16-53-38-509_366be17b9a0d0024.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/64/Propagate-Air-Plants-Step-2.jpg/aid11719527-v4-728px-Propagate-Air-Plants-Step-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn34@2020_4/2020/10/27/16-54-18-250_9a536303dd866492.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f5/Propagate-Air-Plants-Step-3.jpg/aid11719527-v4-728px-Propagate-Air-Plants-Step-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn16@2020_6/2020/10/27/16-54-22-842_c297b17e24e5e1ac.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/86/Propagate-Air-Plants-Step-4.jpg/aid11719527-v4-728px-Propagate-Air-Plants-Step-4.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn3@2020_2/2020/10/27/16-54-22-458_1f64407a491aa920.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a2/Propagate-Air-Plants-Step-5.jpg/aid11719527-v4-728px-Propagate-Air-Plants-Step-5.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn88@2020_4/2020/10/27/16-54-20-865_04337c27e1a39524.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e6/Propagate-Air-Plants-Step-6.jpg/aid11719527-v4-728px-Propagate-Air-Plants-Step-6.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn80@2020_3/2020/10/27/16-54-17-534_7e6a1ef9ad6b3d9f.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/30/Propagate-Air-Plants-Step-7.jpg/aid11719527-v4-728px-Propagate-Air-Plants-Step-7.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn53@2020_5/2020/10/27/16-54-18-300_e008903d74f3e28e.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2f/Propagate-Air-Plants-Step-8.jpg/aid11719527-v4-728px-Propagate-Air-Plants-Step-8.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn96@2020_6/2020/10/27/16-54-22-253_eccbf6c1af24a44a.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/64/Propagate-Air-Plants-Step-9.jpg/aid11719527-v4-728px-Propagate-Air-Plants-Step-9.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn82@2020_6/2020/10/27/16-54-21-580_f806c972af6b2860.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/32/Propagate-Air-Plants-Step-10.jpg/aid11719527-v4-728px-Propagate-Air-Plants-Step-10.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn19@2020_1/2020/10/27/16-54-21-712_d63808ce02c9b913.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/59/Propagate-Air-Plants-Step-11.jpg/aid11719527-v4-728px-Propagate-Air-Plants-Step-11.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn27@2020_4/2020/10/27/16-54-20-248_4ea49eaa5672d58b.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c7/Propagate-Air-Plants-Step-12.jpg/aid11719527-v4-728px-Propagate-Air-Plants-Step-12.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn87@2020_6/2020/10/27/16-54-19-879_5e154086a8ba278a.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/24/Propagate-Air-Plants-Step-13.jpg/aid11719527-v4-728px-Propagate-Air-Plants-Step-13.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn45@2020_1/2020/10/27/16-54-18-972_84e857bed261ada2.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1603817618064},{"createdTime":"2020-10-28 00:53:38","updatedTime":"2020-10-28 00:53:38","title":"How to Cook Without a Recipe","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Cook-Without-a-Recipe","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\">\n <p>Recipes are a great guide for people learning to cook, but you don't have to rely on them if you have good kitchen skills. Practice making a few recipes until you've perfected them. Then, play around with small changes and substitutions. You'll learn how long it takes to make a dish, what seasonings you enjoy using, and how to make a meal out of leftovers. Over time, you won't need the recipe to create a perfectly original dish. </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Cook-Without-a-Recipe&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Cook-Without-a-Recipe&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Learning the Basics\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Learning-the-Basics\">Learning the Basics</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Choose a few simple recipes to master. The more you practice a recipe or cuisine, the easier it will be to cook it from <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Memorize-Recipes-Fast\" title=\"Memorize Recipes Fast\">memory</a> or make your own changes. Look through cookbooks, your family's recipe box, or at food blogs to find recipes that you'd like to try. Then, <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Learn-Cooking-by-Yourself\" title=\"Learn Cooking by Yourself\">make the dish</a> regularly so it always turns out the same way.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cook-Without-a-Recipe#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-1-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Cook Without a Recipe Step 1 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/33/Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid361985-v4-728px-Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-1-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"485\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You might want to focus on a certain cuisine or type of food, such as pizza, pasta, or soup.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Cook with experienced friends and family. If cooking doesn't come easily to you, you might learn better by watching others cook. Although there are lots of cooking shows and food channels, find someone you know who's a good cook and ask to make something with them.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-2-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Cook Without a Recipe Step 2 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/12/Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-2-Version-2.jpg/aid361985-v4-728px-Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-2-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"485\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Cooking with someone will give you hands-on experience and you'll be able to ask questions as you cook. You'll also be able to taste the finished product!</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Look for opportunities to experiment with cooking instead of baking. It's a little easier to cook without a recipe because cooking methods, roasting, boiling, or grilling for instance, don't have to be exact. Try to think of baking like chemistry class and realize that you can't simply leave out or eyeball important ingredients.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cook-Without-a-Recipe#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-3-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Cook Without a Recipe Step 3 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c6/Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-3-Version-2.jpg/aid361985-v4-728px-Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-3-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"485\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you'd like to bake without a recipe, it's important to tweak something that you already know how to make really well. For example, make your favorite blueberry muffins and add cinnamon or swap raspberries for the blueberries. Avoid big changes, like leaving out the eggs or dairy.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Stock your fridge and pantry with <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Stock-Your-Pantry-for-Quick-and-Easy-Meals\" title=\"Stock Your Pantry for Quick and Easy Meals\">staples</a>. Pay attention to ingredients that you buy often and cook with every week. Try to keep these in your fridge or pantry at all times so you can always reach for a familiar ingredient to add to your meal.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cook-Without-a-Recipe#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-4-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Cook Without a Recipe Step 4 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/85/Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-4-Version-2.jpg/aid361985-v4-728px-Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-4-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"485\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>For example, you might always keep pasta, tuna, beans, or marinara sauce in the pantry. Having these staples on hand would allow you to throw together a casserole, pizza, or soup.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Challenge yourself to cook more in order to improve. Frequent practice is the best way to learn cooking, with or without a recipe. Consider where you're already at with your baking skills and set a goal of cooking more or skill building. For example, you might challenge yourself to:<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cook-Without-a-Recipe#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-5-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Cook Without a Recipe Step 5 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5d/Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-5-Version-2.jpg/aid361985-v4-728px-Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-5-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"485\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Improve your knife skills</li> \n    <li>Cook 5 days of the week</li> \n    <li>Cook a meal from a new cuisine</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Take a cooking class if you need more guidance. If you're still struggling to feel comfortable with cooking, check local community centers or cooking supply stores to see if they offer cooking classes. They may do classes on a certain style of food, such as baking bread, making pasta, or baking desserts.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cook-Without-a-Recipe#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-6-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Cook Without a Recipe Step 6 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/90/Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-6-Version-3.jpg/aid361985-v4-728px-Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-6-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"485\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Cook-Without-a-Recipe&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Building Your Confidence\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Building-Your-Confidence\">Building Your Confidence</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Recognize when food is <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Know-if-Food-is-Undercooked\" title=\"Know if Food is Undercooked\">finished cooking</a>. If you don't have a recipe to tell you how long to cook something for, you need to know signs that the food is done, especially when cooking <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cook-Meat\" title=\"Cook Meat\">meat</a> or seafood. To tell if meat is as cooked as you like, rely on an instant-read meat thermometer. If you're baking cake, muffins, or quick bread, you'll usually want to insert a toothpick to see if it comes out clean.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cook-Without-a-Recipe#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-7-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Cook Without a Recipe Step 7 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/23/Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-7-Version-3.jpg/aid361985-v4-728px-Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-7-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"485\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>The more you cook, the better you'll be at gauging how long something takes to cook. For example, if you're <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Stir-Fry\" title=\"Stir Fry\">stir-frying vegetables</a>, you'll know to add carrots before onions since they take longer to cook.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Taste your food frequently and trust your senses. Don't wait until you're ready to serve a meal before you taste it. As long as the food isn't raw, you should be sampling it as you cook so you can adjust the seasonings. Learn to trust your instinct. For example, if the dish tastes like it needs brighter flavor, add a squeeze or lemon or freshly chopped herbs.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cook-Without-a-Recipe#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-8-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Cook Without a Recipe Step 8 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/fe/Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-8-Version-2.jpg/aid361985-v4-728px-Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-8-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"485\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Pay attention to how things smell as you cook. Your sense of smell can tell you if you've added enough spices, if the food smells appetizing, or if something is burning!</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Experiment with a dish before serving it to others. You'll put unnecessary pressure on yourself if you try to whip up something that you've never made before to serve to guests. Instead, practice cooking without a recipe when there's little stress or pressure. You'll enjoy yourself more and might be bolder since there's no fear of making mistakes.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-9-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Cook Without a Recipe Step 9 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/11/Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-9-Version-2.jpg/aid361985-v4-728px-Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-9-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"485\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>It's not a bad idea to have a backup plan, even if you're just cooking dinner for yourself. For example, have supplies in the fridge for making a quick sandwich if cooking doesn't turn out as you hoped.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Make substitutions to dishes you know how to make. Once you've gotten really comfortable with making a particular dish, experiment by changing a few ingredients. For example, if your pasta calls for bacon and asparagus, try making it with pancetta and snap peas.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cook-Without-a-Recipe#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-10-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Cook Without a Recipe Step 10 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c1/Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-10-Version-3.jpg/aid361985-v4-728px-Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-10-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"485\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Pizza is a great meal to cook without a recipe. As long as you can roll out the <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Pizza-Dough\" title=\"Make Pizza Dough\">dough</a>, you can try different sauces or toppings.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Practice seasoning a dish. You may be used to seasoning food with salt, but there are a lot of ways to adjust the flavor of food. In addition to salt, you might want to add more spices or fresh herbs according to your preferences. To really take your cooking to the next level, add a few drops of an acidic ingredient, such as lemon juice, vinegar, wine, or hot sauce.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cook-Without-a-Recipe#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-11-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Cook Without a Recipe Step 11 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/cc/Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-11-Version-2.jpg/aid361985-v4-728px-Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-11-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"485\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>To add richness to the meal, stir in a little butter or heavy cream.</li> \n    <li>If the meal tastes a little boring or flat, add depth of flavor by stirring in some miso, tomato paste, or Worcestershire sauce.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Memorize basic ratios for the foods you cook often. You don't need recipes for foods that rely on simple ratios, such as rice, quinoa, bulgur, and other grains. Find a ratio that creates food with a texture you like and commit it to memory. Then, you can easily make a pot of couscous without even thinking about it.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-12-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Cook Without a Recipe Step 12 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a9/Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-12-Version-2.jpg/aid361985-v4-728px-Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-12-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"485\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Use of water for every 1 cup (180 g) of rice as a starting ratio. Then, adjust the ratio to get a texture you like.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Cook-Without-a-Recipe&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Becoming a Great Cook\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Becoming-a-Great-Cook\">Becoming a Great Cook</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Take notes about what works. Not every dish you create from scratch will be a hit, but you're sure to cook something that you want to make again. Don't wait too long before you write down what you made. This will help you replicate the dish until you can commit it to memory.<sup id=\"_ref-10\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cook-Without-a-Recipe#_note-10\">[10]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-13-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Cook Without a Recipe Step 13 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4d/Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-13-Version-2.jpg/aid361985-v4-728px-Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-13-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"485\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You should also make notes of what didn't work and possible things to try for next time. For example, you could write, \"Don't substitute white chocolate for dark chocolate. Try semisweet instead.\"</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Give yourself enough time to cook. If you don't have a recipe to go off of, you should have a vague understanding of how long it will take to make certain dishes so you don't feel stressed. Keep in mind that meals like pasta, pizza, or stir-fries will come together faster than large cuts of meat, such as roasts.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-14-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Cook Without a Recipe Step 14 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0a/Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-14-Version-2.jpg/aid361985-v4-728px-Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-14-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"485\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Use <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-Leftovers\" title=\"Use Leftovers\">leftovers</a> as the basis for a new meal. This is a great way to reduce food waste and come up with a new meal without a recipe. Take a look through the fridge and pantry to see what food you have and try to come up with a meal that uses several of the ingredients.<sup id=\"_ref-11\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cook-Without-a-Recipe#_note-11\">[11]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-15-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Cook Without a Recipe Step 15 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/89/Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-15-Version-2.jpg/aid361985-v4-728px-Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-15-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"485\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>For example, if you have leftover <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Roast-Vegetables\" title=\"Roast Vegetables\">roasted vegetables</a> and some soft cheese, toss them with cooked noodles to make a casserole. You could also use them as toppings for a quick pizza or mix them into a simple <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cook-a-Basic-Omelette\" title=\"Cook a Basic Omelette\">omelette</a>.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Use your favorite recipes as templates for new dishes. You don't need to start from scratch every time you cook without a recipe. Instead, find recipes you enjoy making and use them as a guide to make new meals.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-16-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Cook Without a Recipe Step 16 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9e/Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-16-Version-2.jpg/aid361985-v4-728px-Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-16-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"485\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>For example, if you have a great curry recipe, try substituting the protein or swapping out the vegetables for an entirely new curry.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Cook within flavor families. Look at the ingredients you have on hand and think about which go well together. Then, try to craft a meal around those flavors. For example, if you're making a simple bean soup, you could use black beans, diced tomatoes, chili powder, garlic, and onion to make a Southwestern-flavored soup. Or you could use different flavors, such as white beans with garlic, thyme, chicken stock, and rosemary.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-17-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Cook Without a Recipe Step 17 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/fa/Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-17-Version-2.jpg/aid361985-v4-728px-Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-17-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"485\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You might find that you're already comfortable cooking a certain cuisine. Think about the ingredients and flavors that are frequently used and try to make them into new dishes.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Relax and enjoy making food. Don't be afraid to make mistakes when you cook and try to cook as often as you can. Working in the kitchen every day will make you feel more capable and confident. Practice really will make it easier to cook meals without a recipe.<sup id=\"_ref-12\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 12\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cook-Without-a-Recipe#_note-12\">[12]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-18-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Cook Without a Recipe Step 18 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a0/Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-18-Version-2.jpg/aid361985-v4-728px-Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-18-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"485\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li>\n </ol> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Cook-Without-a-Recipe&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Tips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tips\">Tips</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Set yourself a goal of cooking 1 meal a week without a recipe. As you become more confident, you can make more original meals throughout the week.</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Cook-Without-a-Recipe&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: Related wikiHows\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Related-wikiHows\">Related wikiHows</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cook\" title=\"Cook\">Cook</a></li> \n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Know-if-Food-is-Undercooked\" title=\"Know if Food is Undercooked\">Know if Food is Undercooked</a></li> \n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Understand-and-Use-Basic-Cooking-Terms-and-Skills\" title=\"Understand and Use Basic Cooking Terms and Skills\">Understand and Use Basic Cooking Terms and Skills</a></li> \n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Write-a-Recipe\" title=\"Write a Recipe\">Write a Recipe</a></li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Cook-Without-a-Recipe&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7\" title=\"Edit section: References\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"References\">References</span></h2>\n <div class=\"mw-references-wrap mw-references-columns\">\n  <ol rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" </li> \n   <li id=\"_note-2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cook-Without-a-Recipe#_ref-2\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer </li> \n   <li id=\"_note-4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cook-Without-a-Recipe#_ref-4\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/jul/23/corn-nuts-cookbooks-and-hot-oil-kitchen-encounters-eve-osullivan\">https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/jul/23/corn-nuts-cookbooks-and-hot-oil-kitchen-encounters-eve-osullivan</a></span> </li> \n   <li id=\"_note-5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cook-Without-a-Recipe#_ref-5\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://uncpressblog.com/2012/01/17/cooking-the-books-12-great-reasons-to-take-a-cooking-class/\">https://uncpressblog.com/2012/01/17/cooking-the-books-12-great-reasons-to-take-a-cooking-class/</a></span> </li> \n   <li id=\"_note-6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cook-Without-a-Recipe#_ref-6\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"http://www.eatingwell.com/article/65068/how-to-cook-without-a-recipe/\">http://www.eatingwell.com/article/65068/how-to-cook-without-a-recipe/</a></span> </li> \n   <li id=\"_note-7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cook-Without-a-Recipe#_ref-7\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"http://www.eatingwell.com/article/65068/how-to-cook-without-a-recipe/\">http://www.eatingwell.com/article/65068/how-to-cook-without-a-recipe/</a></span> </li> \n   <li id=\"_note-8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cook-Without-a-Recipe#_ref-8\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.tasteofhome.com/collection/cooking-without-a-recipe/\">https://www.tasteofhome.com/collection/cooking-without-a-recipe/</a></span> </li> \n   <li id=\"_note-9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cook-Without-a-Recipe#_ref-9\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.thekitchn.com/cooks-tricks-how-to-properly-s-94250\">https://www.thekitchn.com/cooks-tricks-how-to-properly-s-94250</a></span> </li> \n   <li id=\"_note-10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cook-Without-a-Recipe#_ref-10\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"http://www.eatingwell.com/article/65068/how-to-cook-without-a-recipe/\">http://www.eatingwell.com/article/65068/how-to-cook-without-a-recipe/</a></span> </li> \n   <li id=\"_note-11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cook-Without-a-Recipe#_ref-11\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.tasteofhome.com/collection/cooking-without-a-recipe/\">https://www.tasteofhome.com/collection/cooking-without-a-recipe/</a></span> </li> \n   <li id=\"_note-12\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cook-Without-a-Recipe#_ref-12\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.thekitchn.com/my-secret-to-becoming-a-more-confident-cook-life-in-the-kitchen-216576\">https://www.thekitchn.com/my-secret-to-becoming-a-more-confident-cook-life-in-the-kitchen-216576</a></span> </li> \n  </ol>\n </div> \n</div>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 26 Oct 2020 16:00:00 +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/33/Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid361985-v4-728px-Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-1-Version-2.jpg","linkMd5":"f24adff95fa9214bd83b3a15042a0750","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn14@2020_3/2020/10/27/16-53-59-566_c40f088da20a4d8c.webp","destWidth":728,"destHeight":485,"sourceBytes":71949,"destBytes":55590,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/33/Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid361985-v4-728px-Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-1-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn14@2020_3/2020/10/27/16-53-59-566_c40f088da20a4d8c.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/12/Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-2-Version-2.jpg/aid361985-v4-728px-Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-2-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn82@2020_2/2020/10/27/16-54-17-940_da4f2a73c02c6bd7.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c6/Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-3-Version-2.jpg/aid361985-v4-728px-Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-3-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn69@2020_2/2020/10/27/16-54-17-351_3eb97dc81bb1bd91.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/85/Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-4-Version-2.jpg/aid361985-v4-728px-Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-4-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn30@2020_4/2020/10/27/16-54-22-733_3ea6bdfdb5c74a6d.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5d/Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-5-Version-2.jpg/aid361985-v4-728px-Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-5-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn79@2020_6/2020/10/27/16-54-18-506_34e46e03dfe3aec0.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/90/Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-6-Version-3.jpg/aid361985-v4-728px-Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-6-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn41@2020_1/2020/10/27/16-54-18-897_9fa97f8f57b32b6e.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/23/Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-7-Version-3.jpg/aid361985-v4-728px-Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-7-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn16@2020_3/2020/10/27/16-54-20-945_d89f0df007c7dc09.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/fe/Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-8-Version-2.jpg/aid361985-v4-728px-Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-8-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn29@2020_5/2020/10/27/16-54-16-691_168f55a81ae52cf7.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/11/Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-9-Version-2.jpg/aid361985-v4-728px-Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-9-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn11@2020_3/2020/10/27/16-54-20-987_5ee1ec3703055c04.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c1/Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-10-Version-3.jpg/aid361985-v4-728px-Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-10-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn66@2020_4/2020/10/27/16-54-22-064_0263247020c9d00d.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/cc/Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-11-Version-2.jpg/aid361985-v4-728px-Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-11-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn56@2020_2/2020/10/27/16-54-16-200_a2d9dbd09761ac93.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a9/Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-12-Version-2.jpg/aid361985-v4-728px-Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-12-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn16@2020_2/2020/10/27/16-54-15-872_304b0c819704fdae.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4d/Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-13-Version-2.jpg/aid361985-v4-728px-Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-13-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn83@2020_5/2020/10/27/16-54-15-811_5e4a341b3896a5be.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0a/Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-14-Version-2.jpg/aid361985-v4-728px-Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-14-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn20@2020_4/2020/10/27/16-54-22-429_53ed5bf57fd83499.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/89/Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-15-Version-2.jpg/aid361985-v4-728px-Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-15-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn49@2020_5/2020/10/27/16-54-17-190_3972ec56b3325ca1.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9e/Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-16-Version-2.jpg/aid361985-v4-728px-Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-16-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn49@2020_1/2020/10/27/16-54-20-386_2052c71409d62297.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/fa/Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-17-Version-2.jpg/aid361985-v4-728px-Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-17-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn97@2020_3/2020/10/27/16-54-15-989_31685974515cdd6b.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a0/Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-18-Version-2.jpg/aid361985-v4-728px-Cook-Without-a-Recipe-Step-18-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn36@2020_1/2020/10/27/16-54-16-124_3ca7ee516eed0426.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1603817618060},{"createdTime":"2020-10-28 00:53:38","updatedTime":"2020-10-28 00:53:38","title":"How to Create Faded Dyed Sneakers","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Create-Faded-Dyed-Sneakers","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\">\n <p>If you want to create a cool fade on a pair of sneakers, you can easily do it at home with liquid fabric dye. Start with plain, white sneakers made of canvas and buy a liquid fabric dye in a color that you like. Mix the fabric dye with hot water to create a dye bath, then dip-dye your shoes to the depth that you want. After that, rub the shoes at the transition line with a dampened cloth to manually fade the color. Your new kicks will be one-of-a-kind! </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Create-Faded-Dyed-Sneakers&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Create-Faded-Dyed-Sneakers&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Mixing a Dye Bath\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Mixing-a-Dye-Bath\">Mixing a Dye Bath</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Cover your workspace with plastic or newspaper to prevent staining. Fabric dye will stain most surfaces. To prevent stains on your countertops and floor, cover them with a drop cloth, garbage bags, or thick layers of newspaper. If you’re worried about the protective layers shifting around, tape around the edges with masking tape to secure them in place.<br /><br />\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Create-Faded-Dyed-Sneakers-Step-1-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Create Faded Dyed Sneakers Step 1 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/23/Create-Faded-Dyed-Sneakers-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid3742573-v4-728px-Create-Faded-Dyed-Sneakers-Step-1-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Make sure the entire work area is protected.</li> \n    <li>You may also want to keep a roll of paper towels nearby in case of spills.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Put on old clothes and a pair of plastic gloves. Dyeing shoes can be messy! Fabric dye will definitely ruin your clothes, so wear old items that you don’t mind staining. Then, put on a pair of plastic gloves to protect your skin from the dye.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Create-Faded-Dyed-Sneakers#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Create-Faded-Dyed-Sneakers-Step-2-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Create Faded Dyed Sneakers Step 2 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a6/Create-Faded-Dyed-Sneakers-Step-2-Version-3.jpg/aid3742573-v4-728px-Create-Faded-Dyed-Sneakers-Step-2-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you can’t change your clothes right now, try wearing a long apron or smock over them.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Fill a plastic container or sink with of hot water. Ideally, the water should be around . You can use an instant-read thermometer to check the temperature. If your tap water doesn’t get that hot, heat the water up in a large pot or kettle on your stove. Then, transfer the hot water to your plastic container or stainless steel sink.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Create-Faded-Dyed-Sneakers#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup><br /><br />\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Create-Faded-Dyed-Sneakers-Step-3-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Create Faded Dyed Sneakers Step 3 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5f/Create-Faded-Dyed-Sneakers-Step-3-Version-3.jpg/aid3742573-v4-728px-Create-Faded-Dyed-Sneakers-Step-3-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you don’t have an instant-read thermometer on hand, heat up the water to just below boiling.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Create-Faded-Dyed-Sneakers#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup></li> \n    <li>If you don’t have a stainless steel sink, use a plastic container. The fabric dye might stain other sink materials.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Add of liquid dish soap to the hot water. Use a measuring spoon to measure out the liquid dish soap and pour it into the plastic container or sink with the water. Use a wooden spoon to stir the hot water so the dish soap distributes evenly. Stir gently so that you don’t create suds!<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Create-Faded-Dyed-Sneakers#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>The dish soap helps the dye spread out evenly in the hot water.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Stir of liquid fabric dye into the hot water. Decide what color you want to dye your shoes and buy matching liquid fabric dye. Shake up the liquid dye in its original container before measuring the liquid dye out. Then, dump the dye into the hot water and stir with a wooden spoon to distribute it. Be gentle to avoid splashing the dye bath.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Create-Faded-Dyed-Sneakers#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you want very vibrant results, try using of fabric dye instead.</li> \n    <li>If you want to dye your shoes different colors, or if you’re dyeing multiple pairs of shoes in different colors, create a separate dye bath for each color.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Create-Faded-Dyed-Sneakers&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Dip-Dyeing the Shoes\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Dip-Dyeing-the-Shoes\">Dip-Dyeing the Shoes</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Buy white canvas sneakers or <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-Canvas-Sneakers\" title=\"Clean Canvas Sneakers\">clean a pair that you already own</a>. White sneakers without logos or patterns on them will give you the results you want. It’s extremely difficult to control the fade effect if your shoes aren’t completely white and made of canvas. Other fabrics, like real (or faux) leather, won’t take the dye very well.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Create-Faded-Dyed-Sneakers#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Create-Faded-Dyed-Sneakers-Step-6-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Create Faded Dyed Sneakers Step 6 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/87/Create-Faded-Dyed-Sneakers-Step-6-Version-3.jpg/aid3742573-v4-728px-Create-Faded-Dyed-Sneakers-Step-6-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>The only exception are women’s silk bridal or formal shoes. They still need to be white or off-white, though.</li> \n    <li>If you’re dyeing a pair of sneakers that you already own, make sure they’re stain-free! Stains and other discolorations will interfere with dye absorption.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Remove the shoelaces and insoles from your sneakers. Unlace the shoelaces and set them aside for now. If your shoes have removable insoles, go ahead and take those out, as well. Be sure to place the laces and insoles well out of reach so they won’t get stained by accidental splashes or drips.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Create-Faded-Dyed-Sneakers#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup><br /><br /></li> \n  <li>Run the canvas parts of the shoes under a faucet to wet them. The canvas will accept the dye better if you get it wet first. Simply run the canvas parts of your shoes under a water faucet to thoroughly wet them. It doesn’t matter what water temperature you use for this.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Create-Faded-Dyed-Sneakers#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Create-Faded-Dyed-Sneakers-Step-8-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Create Faded Dyed Sneakers Step 8 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2b/Create-Faded-Dyed-Sneakers-Step-8-Version-2.jpg/aid3742573-v4-728px-Create-Faded-Dyed-Sneakers-Step-8-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Smear a thin layer of petroleum jelly over the rubber soles. You can use your fingers or a paintbrush to apply the petroleum jelly to the soles—just make sure you cover the rubber surface thoroughly! Don't forget the rubber sole parts along the sides of the shoes.<br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>The petroleum jelly prevents the dye from staining the rubber.</li> \n    <li>If you’re dyeing silk bridal shoes, skip this step. Petroleum jelly will stain silk.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Hold 1 shoe in each hand and line them up side by side. Grab the left shoe in your left hand and the right shoe in your right hand. Line the heels and toes up so that the shoes are perfectly parallel.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Create-Faded-Dyed-Sneakers#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Create-Faded-Dyed-Sneakers-Step-10-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Create Faded Dyed Sneakers Step 10 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/46/Create-Faded-Dyed-Sneakers-Step-10-Version-2.jpg/aid3742573-v4-728px-Create-Faded-Dyed-Sneakers-Step-10-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Dyeing both shoes at the same time is easier and ensures that you get matching results.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Position both shoes with either the heels or the toes pointed down. How you position the shoes depends on where you want the color to appear—the toes or the heel. Either way will work. Dip-dyeing with the toes down is probably a little easier, but it’s completely up to you.<sup id=\"_ref-10\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Create-Faded-Dyed-Sneakers#_note-10\">[10]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Create-Faded-Dyed-Sneakers-Step-11-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Create Faded Dyed Sneakers Step 11 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e2/Create-Faded-Dyed-Sneakers-Step-11-Version-2.jpg/aid3742573-v4-728px-Create-Faded-Dyed-Sneakers-Step-11-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Don’t forget to keep the shoes parallel once you decide on the orientation.</li> \n    <li>The only exception is if you’re dyeing the shoes different colors. In that case, dip 1 shoe at a time in separate dye baths or simply put the dye baths next to each other and dip the shoes simultaneously.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Lower the shoes slowly into the dye bath to the depth you want. How deep you dip your shoes is up to you, but keep in mind that the color will spread a little further on the shoes when you create the fading effect. Give yourself about to work with if you want your shoes to fade to white.<sup id=\"_ref-11\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Create-Faded-Dyed-Sneakers#_note-11\">[11]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>For example, if you want your color to start fading at the middle of the shoes, dip the toes up to the lace holes. The color will extend to the center portion of the shoes when you manually create the fading effect.</li> \n    <li>How far the fade extends is also customizable because you will create the gradation yourself.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Hold the shoes in the dye bath for about 2 minutes. Be as still as possible while you’re holding the shoes in the dye bath so that you get even results! Keep your eye on the time or use a timer to keep track. After 2 minutes, pull the shoes out of the dye bath.<sup id=\"_ref-12\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 12\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Create-Faded-Dyed-Sneakers#_note-12\">[12]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Create-Faded-Dyed-Sneakers-Step-13-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Create Faded Dyed Sneakers Step 13 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3b/Create-Faded-Dyed-Sneakers-Step-13-Version-2.jpg/aid3742573-v4-728px-Create-Faded-Dyed-Sneakers-Step-13-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Inspect the color and dip the shoes again if you want it darker. Check out the color you’ve achieved so far. Keep in mind that the color will look darker when the shoes are wet; once they dry, the shade will be a little lighter. If you want darker results, dip the shoes into the dye bath again. Check on them in 30-60 second intervals until you reach the color you want.<sup id=\"_ref-13\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 13\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Create-Faded-Dyed-Sneakers#_note-13\">[13]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you dip your shoes more than once, don’t forget to dip them at the original depth every time.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Create-Faded-Dyed-Sneakers&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Creating the Fade Effect\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Creating-the-Fade-Effect\">Creating the Fade Effect</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Rinse the dyed parts of your shoes with cool water until it runs clear. Hold the dyed portion of your shoe under the faucet and rinse the shoes, one at a time, with cool water. Concentrate the water only on the dyed parts of the canvas. Keep rinsing until the water runs clear.<sup id=\"_ref-14\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 14\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Create-Faded-Dyed-Sneakers#_note-14\">[14]</a></sup><br /><br /></li> \n  <li>Rub the canvas with a damp cloth where the color meets white. Dampen a clean, soft cloth with water. Then, gently rub along the transition line where the color meets the white part of the canvas until the harsh line blurs. Keep rubbing until there are no visible harsh lines on the canvas.<sup id=\"_ref-15\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 15\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Create-Faded-Dyed-Sneakers#_note-15\">[15]</a></sup><br /><br />\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Create-Faded-Dyed-Sneakers-Step-16-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Create Faded Dyed Sneakers Step 16 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/92/Create-Faded-Dyed-Sneakers-Step-16-Version-2.jpg/aid3742573-v4-728px-Create-Faded-Dyed-Sneakers-Step-16-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If the color is being stubborn, wet the cloth again and keep rubbing.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Drag the damp cloth through the color toward the white area. For example, if you dip-dyed the toes of your shoes and you want the color to slowly fade to white around the halfway mark, drag the damp cloth through the dye from the toe to the transition area. Then, move a little further down the toe and drag again. Continue this process until you reach the gradation you want.<sup id=\"_ref-16\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 16\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Create-Faded-Dyed-Sneakers#_note-16\">[16]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>The color should transition smoothly from dark to light.</li> \n    <li>Work as quickly as possible, since the canvas needs to be wet to create this effect.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Wash the shoes in warm water with gentle detergent. Once you’ve achieved the faded look you want, put the shoes into your washing machine. Use a warm water setting and a gentle cycle. Add a small amount of gentle laundry detergent before starting the cycle. <sup id=\"_ref-17\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 17\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Create-Faded-Dyed-Sneakers#_note-17\">[17]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Create-Faded-Dyed-Sneakers-Step-18-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Create Faded Dyed Sneakers Step 18 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a4/Create-Faded-Dyed-Sneakers-Step-18-Version-2.jpg/aid3742573-v4-728px-Create-Faded-Dyed-Sneakers-Step-18-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Let the shoes air-dry completely. Take the shoes out of the washing machine and lay them on a towel to dry. Once your shoes are completely dry, put the laces and insoles back in and try them on! They’re ready to wear as long as they’re dry.<sup id=\"_ref-18\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 18\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Create-Faded-Dyed-Sneakers#_note-18\">[18]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Create-Faded-Dyed-Sneakers-Step-19.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Create Faded Dyed Sneakers Step 19.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/00/Create-Faded-Dyed-Sneakers-Step-19.jpg/aid3742573-v4-728px-Create-Faded-Dyed-Sneakers-Step-19.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li>\n </ol> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Create-Faded-Dyed-Sneakers&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Video\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Video\">Video</span></h2> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Create-Faded-Dyed-Sneakers&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: Tips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tips\">Tips</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Let the shoes to dry in a cool place for a faster dry time. Avoid humid areas.</li> \n  <li>Dispose of remaining dye bath according to the package directions.</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Create-Faded-Dyed-Sneakers&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7\" title=\"Edit section: Things You’ll Need\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span id=\"Things-You’ll-Need\"></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Things-You.E2.80.99ll-Need\">Things You’ll Need</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>White canvas shoes</li> \n  <li>Old clothes</li> \n  <li>Plastic gloves</li> \n  <li>Petroleum jelly</li> \n  <li>Dropcloth, plastic, or newspaper</li> \n  <li>5-gallon bucket or access to a stainless steel sink</li> \n  <li>Liquid fabric dye</li> \n  <li>Wooden spoon</li> \n  <li>Paper towels</li> \n  <li>Several clean clothes</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Create-Faded-Dyed-Sneakers&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8\" title=\"Edit section: Related wikiHows\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Related-wikiHows\">Related wikiHows</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Pair-of-%22Vintage%22-Converse\" title=\"Make a Pair of &quot;Vintage&quot; Converse\">Make a Pair of \"Vintage\" Converse</a></li> \n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Wash-Shoes\" title=\"Wash Shoes\">Wash Shoes</a></li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Create-Faded-Dyed-Sneakers&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9\" title=\"Edit section: References\">Edit</a><span
